‎• That being said, you must (outside of very niche cases without ) always ensure that when you do an auto into a channelled, that the channelled ability is done with DW (this is mostly important for Asphyxiate , as Concentrated Blast is already DW locked, and Smoke Tendrils is not relevant) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This is because of the fact that when the channelled hits it incurs your auto cd, it is going to incurs it based off the weapon you are wearing, thus if you staff , when your ends your auto is on a 6t cooldown again ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- The table below will showcase two different scenarios: 2H Asphyxiate: You MUST do: Auto + Asphyxiate → Ability → DW Ability → Auto + Ability DW Asphyxiate: You can do: Auto + Asphyxiate → DW Ability → Auto + Ability Note: this is not an issue if you do auto + ability → → non-channelled DW ability → repeat structure, given the fact you are already planning to auto 2 abilities after 4TAA Guides Video Guide by #Aiex https://youtu.be/HmZR1BBwsK0 Text Based Guide ⬥ The basic principles is you can do lossless spellcasting by hitting a spell from action bar (lossless meaning you don't lose ticks performing the action) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This lets you auto the same tick as you use an ability (input is auto → ability) ⬥ When you can autoattack is based on a delay depending on your weapon speed: = 4t and = 6t ⬥ ‎ ‎Your delay after an action is given by max(currentdelay, delay from action) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Implications from this are that if you do a wand ability you'll be able to autoattack 4 ticks after. If you do a staff ability, you will be able to autoattack 6 ticks after Step-By-Step 4TAA Walkthrough ⬥ Things you need: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Wand + Orb ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Staff ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Runes ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• An ability bar with the basic abilities: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Greater Concentrated Blast , Sonic Wave and a couple other basic abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Wrack ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Auto Attack (such as ) Note 1: is being used for practice solely due to its short cooldown, in actual PvM you should almost never be using this ability Note 2: is being used only for demonstration and cheap rune cost, replace as desired when PvMing ⬥ As touched on earlier, there are two fundamental patterns to 4TAA revolving around Greater Concentrated Blast ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Method A will be: 2H + DW/Staff ability → → DW ability → Repeat ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Method B will be: 2H + → DW/Staff ability → DW ability → Repeat Method A 1. Equip DW , acquire target, and Wrack 2. Equip Staff , wait 1 tick after GCD, then ( + ) in that order on the same tick 3. Equip DW , and Gconc 4. DW Wrack 5. Repeat from step 2 https://youtu.be/Ezn1gJpfRbs Method B 1. Equip DW , acquire a target, and Gconc 2. Cast a basic ability, for example, Dragon Breath (prefer DW to retain crit buff) 3. DW Wrack 4. Equip Staff , wait 1 tick after GCD, then ( + equip DW + ) in that order on the same tick 5. Repeat from step 2 https://youtu.be/NeWln6VcSSc 4TAA Additional Info ⬥ It can be helpful to practice on a combat dummy set to max hit mode, in order to more easily track whether or not you are properly executing 2H autos ⬥ Ensure that for necessary steps, all required actions are done within a single tick ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• For example, from method B, actions in the parentheses must be executed in one tick, in a specific order: DW ability + Equip staff → ( 2H + equip DW + ) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• To make this easier on yourself try keybinding your Wand/Orb/Auto in an easy to reach set of keybinds ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Some players prefer to click their auto attacks instead of keybind them, or in some cases even click their weapons. Such alternatives can be explored at the player's discretion ⬥ You will know you did not lose any ticks between auto and abilities if you do not see the auto firing animation, but the auto itself still fires 4TAA Troubleshooting While practising you may be unsure if you are messing up or not, so the following clips will showcase various scenarios: too fast, correctly, and too slow Note: the Auto damage in all the following clips is 2515 Too Fast This means you simply did not wait the additional tick required for the auto, and so casted your ability at GCD end instead of 1 tick after GCD end to get an Auto + Ability Correctly This means you did it correctly, this will demonstrate how it looks like in both Normals and Ancients Spellbooks ⬥ If you did not mess up on Normals, you will not get the Auto casting animation and you will see the auto still be fired out. ⬥ If you did not mess up on Ancients, you will not get the Auto casting animation. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• As you can also see, the Auto and Ability are cast as the GCD bar flashes Too Slow This means you were too late to cast your auto + ability, typically this results in a 5TAA (auto cast on tick 4, ability cast on tick 5), or worse (ability cast far later) More specifically, it means your ability will be delayed as your auto will automatically fire on the 4th tick either way, assuming you did not off Fractured Staff of Armadyl Note: Many variations of FSOA rotations exist, and crit RNG is involved. This is simply a reference to start from An Overview of FSOA Usage ⬥ The Staff of Armadyl's immensely powerful special attack, Instability , consists of two components: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• An initial hit of 50%-200% ability damage ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Firing an auto-attack when a critical hit is landed ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- The auto casts the tick the hit lands ⬥ Auto-attacks released by can themselves crit. In such cases, auto-attacks will be fired recursively ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Recursively-fired auto-attacks will only occur if the critical hit lands on the primary target ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Crits on additional targets (such as from ) will not trigger the effect ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The damage of fired auto-attacks is determined by the equipped weapon when fired ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- For this reason, a 2H weapon should be preferred over dual-wields ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Fired auto-attacks will not interrupt channelled abilities; however, they will incur auto-attack cooldown ⬥ Due to Instability being focused around critical hits, it has excellent synergy with Tsunami for adrenaline generation from both abilities and subsequent auto-attacks ⬥ The special attack costs 50% adrenaline, lasts for 30 seconds, and has a cooldown of 60 seconds Key Considerations ⬥ An effective Staff of Armadyl rotation is made possible through landing critical hits with 2H equipped as often, and reliably as possible ⬥ As a result, Biting 4 , Erethdor's Grimoire , and a Reaver's Ring are essential ⬥ A Channeller's Ring is generally considered, at best, a marginal gain for Armadyl Battlestaff only. It is neither necessary, nor recommendable at its current price ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It does not affect the crit chance of autos produced by channelled abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Generally, it is considered very low priority ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Reaver's Ring is significantly better than Channeller's Ring if only one is camped ⬥ Generally, is the only dual-wield ability worth using under spec ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• As touched on above, care should be taken so as not to equip dual-wields after abilities such as , or channelled abilities, as this can result in MH autos being fired even if the abilities themselves were cast with 2H ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It is possible to → ability + equip in that order, same-tick, to receive the crit buff on the subsequent ability, and allow hit 3 of and the subsequent ability to fire 2H autos if they crit Basic Example Rotation ⬥ You can extend, modify, and improvise upon this rotation based on the particular situation and your crit RNG ⬥ Auto-cast is assumed to be Incite Fear until at least Tsunami ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Manual spellcasting is assumed to be enabled; therefore is simply used to 4TAA ⬥ Usage of the Igneous Kal-Mej and Conservation of Energy relic are assumed ⬥ Once is active, preferably use 2H for all abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Greater Concentrated Blast can be used to build adren mid-spec, keeping in mind the limitations specified above ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Smoke Tendrils will always crit each of its 4 hits ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This means it will fire at least 4 auto-attacks ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- It will also generate a large amount of guaranteed adrenaline under Tsunami → → → (optional strong basic, i.e. ) → → → ( if needed) → ( if needed) → → → → → Improvise Spell Swapping ⬥ Swapping auto-cast spells during an FSOA rotation can provide a host of benefits depending on the situation. Swapping will generally occur after necessary Incite Fear stacks are achieved for Tsunami ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Swapping to Blood Barrage , especially in AOE situations, can provide an immense amount of healing. As well, its fast hit timing can mean additional auto-attacks fitting within buffs from , , or itself ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Camping Incite Fear allows Frost Surge procs during , which have a chance to crit and subsequently fire auto-attacks ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Swapping to Exsanguinate allows for ability casts to build stacks that can benefit any usages of under ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- It may also grant more efficient access to after the spec has finished General Sunshine Rotations This section will just detail a rough idea of strong abilities to fit in to your Sunshine with the following unlocks assumed: ⬥ Planted Feet ⬥ Igneous Kal-Mej ⬥ Blast Diffusion Boots ⬥ Incite Fear used for Tsunami Note 1: this is simply a basis to work from. It will not necessarily be applicable at all bosses or all scenarios Note 2: if Igneous Kal-Mej is not unlocked, substitute with more Guthix Staff and flank Deep Impact Note 3: Conservation of Energy is recommended for adrenaline refunds from , , and in order to execute a stronger rotation Adrenaline Renewal Sushine ⬥ 2x Wild Magic ⬥ 2x Asphyxiate (2-hit) ⬥ 1x Igneous Omnipower ⬥ 1x Detonate (3t, with auto + ability release) ⬥ Guthix Staff as adrenaline permits Adrenaline Renewal Sushine with Pre-Tsunami ⬥ 2x Igneous Omnipower ⬥ 2x Wild Magic ⬥ 2x Asphyxiate (2-hit) ⬥ 1x Detonate (3t, with auto + ability release) ⬥ Guthix Staff as adrenaline permits Limitless Sunshine ⬥ 1x Tsunami (ideally use before Sunshine) ⬥ 2x Wild Magic ⬥ 2x Asphyxiate (2-hit) ⬥ 1x Igneous Omnipower ⬥ 1x Detonate (3t, with auto + ability release) ⬥ Guthix Staff as adrenaline permits No Limitless/Adren Renewal Sunshine ⬥ 1x Tsunami (ideally use before Sunshine) ⬥ 2x Wild Magic ⬥ 2x Asphyxiate (2-hit) ⬥ 1x Igneous Omnipower ⬥ 1x Detonate (3t, with auto + ability release) ⬥ Guthix Staff as adrenaline permits Table of Contents Begin [Introduction]($linkmsg [General Background Knowledge]($linkmsg [General Background Knowledge]($linkmsg generalInfo$) Building Blocks [Ability Prioritizations and Building a Rotation]($linkmsg [Ability Information]($linkmsg [Ability Information]($linkmsg Info$) [What Spell to Use]($linkmsg To Learn [Cancelling Channels]($linkmsg [Detonate]($linkmsg [Detonate]($linkmsg Deto$) [Dual Wield vs Staff Camp]($linkmsg [Defensive Autos]($linkmsg [Defensive Autos]($linkmsg DefAutos$) [Switches]($linkmsg [4TAA]($linkmsg [4TAA]($linkmsg 4TAA$) [4TAA Guides]($linkmsg [4TAA Troubleshooting]($linkmsg [4TAA Troubleshooting]($linkmsg Aid$) [Fractured Staff of Armadyl]($linkmsg Examples [General Sun Rotations]($linkmsg

docs.text: ⬥ In RuneScape PvM, the meta at the time of writing is about pushing out as much damage in as little time as possible. It is important to understand that good and efficient PvM, especially at the higher tiers, is about squeezing out as much damage as possible in between mechanics. This channel will go over general damage output lessons, ability prioritizations, crafting a rotation, a learning path, common mistakes, and tips and tricks.

docs.text: Ability Prioritization ⬥ Generally speaking, high damaging abilities should be prioritized and used more often than low damaging abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• However, there's a catch: high damaging abilities often come with long cooldowns ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- If you use all of the high damaging abilities at once, you will be forced to wait for cooldowns before you may use them again. During this time you are forced to use weak abilities ⬥ To avoid this problem, the trick is to use filler abilities (ones with decent damage and short cooldowns) in-between your high damaging abilities in order to pace your cooldowns ⬥ See this image for an idea of which abilities should be prioritized based on damage per tick (in a vacuum): Note: You should not necessarily use abilities in the listed order due to aforementioned reasons Building a Rotation ⬥ When building a rotation, ability prioritizations and cooldowns should be on your mind ⬥ You generally will want to prioritize building up to 100% adrenaline and activating Sunshine as soon as possible ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Ideally, enter the encounter with 100% adrenaline so you may activate it immediately upon entry ⬥ Both within and outside of Sunshine , you will want to prioritize your strong thresholds, special attacks, and modified ultimates. These include Igneous Omnipower , Wild Magic , Asphyxiate , flanking Deep Impact , and Guthix Staff ⬥ Greater Concentrated Blast should form the foundation of your rotation. It is a very powerful basic ability with a short cooldown and provides a critical strike chance buff on a subsequent ability ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Use often as a filler ability, in-between other strong basics (Wrack and Ruin , Dragon Breath , Corruption Blast , flanking Impact , and walked Combust ) and the aforementioned thresholds, modified ultimates, and special attacks ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• A basic pattern of → Ability → Ability → repeat is recommended ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If not yet unlocked, or if camping 2H, can be substituted with Concentrated Blast (2-hit) or Sonic Wave , respectively ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The critical chance buff gained through / is wasted if the follow-up ability is a bleed ( / ) ⬥ Any basic ability with damage lower than Sonic Wave or Concentrated Blast is considered a weak ability (Wrack , Tuska's Wrath , Sacrifice , non-flank Impact , Chain , unwalked Combust ) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• These should be largely avoided ⬥ Juggling both DW and 2H weapons gives you access to both (Greater) Concentrated Blast / , and Sonic Wave as filler abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This may provide you with more breathing room while improvising rotations ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Care should be taken while weapon juggling so as not to delay usage of if unlocked. In this case, should only be used as a fallback to take the place of a weaker ability ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If is not yet unlocked, a general pattern of → Ability → → Ability → repeat is recommended ⬥ Generally, if using Exsanguinate , it is recommended to use Wrack and Ruin if the alternative is weaker than Dragon Breath ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This means Blood Tithe stacks can be retained to boost strong basics such as or , while saving for a future time where a weak ability would have to be used otherwise

Combust and corruption blast don't get reduced. ⬥ Wrack ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Cooldown: 5t (3s) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Damage boosted on stun/bound targets: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Becomes a 37.6%-188% basic ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Not affected by Impatient ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Affected by Energizing: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Gain (Energizing Rank * 0.6) more adrenaline ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Damage range is now 0.8 * original damage range ⬥ Wrack and Ruin ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Cooldown: 5t (3s) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Significantly stronger variant of regular Wrack ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Damage increases to 60%-300% ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Made available after reaching 12 stacks of Blood Tithe through auto-casting Exsanguinate ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Damage boosted on stun/bound targets: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Becomes a 120%-360% basic ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Not affected by Impatient ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Affected by Energizing: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Gain (Energizing Rank * 0.6) more adrenaline ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Damage range is now 0.8 * original damage range ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• All stacks of Blood Tithe will be lost after using , meaning the 1%-per-stack damage buff is lost on all non-bleed basic abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This means it is advisable to delay usage of if strong basics such as or are available in order to retain the buff on those abilities ⬥ Magma Tempest ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Cooldown: 25t (15s) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Is a 5x5 area-of-effect ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Hits every 1.2 seconds (2 ticks) over 9.6 seconds for a total of 8 hits ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Cannot critical strike ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Has two variants ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Targeted will not be triggered by revolution. docs.text: Note: these are just general guidelines What Autocast to Use ⬥ Generally, prefer Exsanguinate ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If you plan to utilize Tsunami , use Incite Fear to get 5 stacks, then swap to ⬥ If the City of Senntisten quest is not yet completed, use Blood Barrage ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The quest should be completed as soon as possible ⬥ If on the standard/normal spellbook, use Air Surge ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Use the highest rank of air spell available if is not yet unlocked What Auto to Use Note 1: This refers to the auto on your bar you would be using for 4-tick Auto Attacking (4TAA) or casting Defensive Autos Note 2: the use of weaker spell variants assumes manual spellcasting is used, use !manualspellcasting in #bot-commands for more details ⬥ Generally Blood spells ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Barrage/Burst / if AoE or faster hit timings matter ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Blitz/Rush / otherwise ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Can use Exsanguinate instead if healing does not matter ⬥ Ice spells when you need or will benefit from the freeze: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Use Barrage/Burst / or Blitz/Rush / following same logic for Blood spells ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Note that and have shorter freeze durations than their counterparts ⬥ If on the standard/normal spellbook, use Air Surge/Strike / Debuff Spells to Use ⬥ You should always have Vulnerability applied, and generally you should always have Smoke Cloud applied, unless the boss is immune to such conditions ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Generally, it is always preferred to use Vulnerability bombs instead of the spell ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Bombs are lossless to apply, whereas the spell is not ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Cost of bombs is negligible for most mid-tier or higher content ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Immune creatures: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Vorago ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Araxxor / Araxxi ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Rise of the Six ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Sinister Fragments at Ambassador ⬥ Use Entangle if you need the long bind and the fact that is does no damage is irrelevant

docs.text: Why to Cancel ⬥ Magic has four channelled abilities, and one channelled special attack ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Greater Concentrated Blast ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Concentrated Blast ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Asphyxiate ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Smoke Tendrils ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Armadyl Battlestaff ⬥ It is important to properly cancel abilities in order to not lose any ticks, or damage potential ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Animations can be unreliable, and longer than the actual duration of the ability ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It can be higher damage-per-tick to cancel long channels early ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Greater Concentrated Blast suffers a 1t delay when revolution is enabled When to Cancel Channels ⬥ Almost without exception, cancel Concentrated Blast on its 2nd hit as Global Cooldown ends (3t/1.8s) ⬥ If revolution is enabled, Greater Concentrated Blast should be "cancelled" as Global Cooldown ends (3t/1.8s) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This is not really a cancel, as the ability itself is a 3t channel. It simply avoids the 1t delay caused by revolution ⬥ Typically you will cancel your Asphyxiate on the either the 2nd hit as Global Cooldown ends (3t/1.8s), or the 4th hit (7t/4.2s) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• 2-hit can net higher damage-per-tick, or higher adren gain, when compared to 4-hit ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- → → is still a strong option, especially if not 4taa ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• To cancel on the 3rd hit you would cancel on t5 (3s) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- The above cancel timings are the same for Smoke Tendrils ⬥ The Armadyl Battlestaff special attack is generally used for its full duration of 5t (3s) ⬥ For a visual guide on cancelling, reference this video https://youtu.be/DaCy60sZav4
docs.title: Cancelling Channels

docs.text: What Makes Detonate Unique ⬥ Detonate is not technically a channel; however, it is often considered one as a result of its unique charge-and-release mechanism. This section describes Detonate and dives into how it is different than previously described channels ⬥ Unlike other channels, Detonate : ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Acts similar to a defensive in the context of defensive autos. Auto cooldown is not incurred until its release, meaning you can release it with an auto ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Example: charge → auto + release ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You can do the following while charging, without interrupting the ability: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Throw Vulnerability Bombs ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Spellbook swap ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Shield Dome ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You can stall its release ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Generally speaking you cannot stall channels (outside of melees wherein only 1 hit is stalled) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It is not affected by the Channeller's Ring ⬥ Typically, when releasing Detonate you will release it with both the aforementioned auto, as well as an ability ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Example: → (3t/1.8s) → ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- The hit timing and input order here is crucial: + + must be executed in exactly that order, on the same tick ⬥ There is an odd occurrence wherein Detonate will cost 30% adrenaline instead of 15% ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This can be explained as follows: the game thinks you both have a target and not at the same time, so it uses adrenaline from both your target and the adrenaline inherently used from using it without a target ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- To prevent this, try casting any damaging ability before Detonate ⬥ Further, Detonate works like normal AoEs wherein it is centered at the true center of the target (for any >=2x2 target this will be the SW tile) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If you cast without a target, it will be centered on your player ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If you cast with a target, and the target dies before you release, then: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- If you target cycle onto another target, the explosion will remain centered on the original (dead) target position ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- If you do not target cycle, the explosion will center onto the player ⬥ There exists a bug where casting Detonate on the tick your target dies will cancel the charge completely ⬥ The AoE size of Detonate is dependent on the charge amount on release, as represented in the following diagram:

docs.text: Note: this section is meant to list the benefits of camping one over the other though it is strongly recommended to just juggle, as it gives access to all the following benefits, and more Dual Wield Camp Benefits ⬥ Access to Greater Concentrated Blast ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This is an immensely powerful basic and can be used every 3 abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- also boasts much better synergy with the City of Senntisten spells compared to Sonic Wave ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Its strength means that camping dual wields, even if they are several weapon tiers lower, can be significantly stronger than camping 2H ⬥ Easier swapping ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You can swap to a shield , flanking switch , or caroming switch more easily, as you do not need to do an additional mainhand swap Staff Camp Benefits ⬥ Access to 2H Autos ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• When staff camping this lets you make use of Defensive Autos to replace weaker abilities like Tuska's Wrath which you would otherwise have to use due to lack of abilities ⬥ Can be more revolution-friendly on low HP mobs, such as for Slayer
docs.title: Dual Wield vs Staff Camp

docs.text: Note 1: While this section is colloquially referred to as "Defensive Autos", it is more technically correct to refer to them as "non-damaging". Additional examples of such abilities include Sunshine , Metamorphosis , and targeted Magma Tempest Note 2: Air Surge is again used to signify autos for demonstration purposes only Why Defensive Autos Exist ⬥ Generally, casting any ability will put your auto-attack on cooldown based on the weapon speed of your weapon ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Staff ability (average speed) will place it on a 6t (3.6s) cooldown ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Wand/Orb ability (fastest speed) will place it on a 4t (2.4s) cooldown ⬥ Non-damaging abilities are the exception to this: when cast, they will not incur auto cooldown ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This has several implications, the first applies to all styles, the second is magic specific Implications ⬥ Firstly, this means if you cast a dual wield ability into a defensive ability, your auto will happen mid-Global Cooldown (GCD) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Normally this will be whatever you have set as your autocasted spell, however you can alter what will be cast with the defensive by doing the spell (e.g., Ice Barrage or Entangle ) then the defensive ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The following table will break down the ticks of this: T0: Wand Ability T3: Non-Damaging/Defensive Ability T4: Auto is cast T6: Ability ‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Further, you can exploit this to make it a 2H Auto , as the cooldown for any Auto ends on t4, so you would simply swap to a 2H weapon somewhere between the DW ability cast and the defensive cast, or right after the defensive cast and before the Auto would be cast (this then puts your 2H auto on a 6t (3.6s) cd where you wont be able to cast it at all) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• A further consideration, is if that ability on t6 is a non-channelled DW ability, you can 4tick an ability afterwards ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This can be seen in the following video by #Glaucon https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UmsbPrkqrtw ⬥ Secondly, a benefit magic has, due to it having auto binds, is that you can make sure an auto + ability is cast on the same tick (rather than an auto is cast on 1 tick, and the ability a tick after) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This allows magic to do a 2H ability into a defensive auto as a result ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The following table will break down the ticks of this: T0: Staff Ability T3: Non-Damaging/Defensive Ability T6: Auto + Ability ‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• For Melee and Ranged this would result in: T0: Average Speed 2H Ability T3: Defensive T6: Auto T7: Ability ⬥ It is important to note that Freedom works a little differently, in that you will get both an off-hand and a main-hand/2H auto ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You will always get the off-hand auto, and what is cast as an off-hand auto can be changed by casting the auto before, but on the same tick, as Freedom ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- If you wanted to change what the 2H auto is, you would have to 3 tick it ⬥ It is also important to note that if you click anything from your inventory, or click the ground anywhere, before the auto would naturally fire then you must re-click your target ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• With Magic, hitting your auto bind yields the same result Delaying Defensive Auto ⬥ Based off this fact, you can make use of this if you need to delay a defensive auto for whatever reason ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• More specifically, this can be useful for Freedom if you need to change what both the off-hand and 2H auto are when casting Freedom after a faster than Average speed weapon, as you can only change the 2H Auto if you 3t it ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The following examples will be done with Freedom , however the same idea applies to delaying the auto with other non-damaging abilities, except that you only have the 2H Auto and that you can off any time after your ability before the defensive and by the time the Auto should be cast ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• For Freedom specifically, we will "off" to delay the auto directly after the OH Auto is cast, otherwise we lose the OH Auto ⬥ There are several ways to "off" to delay the auto, these include: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Clicking under yourself ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Clicking a spell you cannot cast (e.g., trying to cast Disruption Shield when on the Ancient Spellbook) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Clicking something from your inventory Note: If you do any of these things before or directly as you cast your defensive normally you will either have to click or hit your auto bind again to actually cast your auto. ⬥ There are also a couple differences between hitting your auto bind to cast your auto and clicking to cast your auto after you "off", they are as follows: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You cannot hit your auto bind to try and recast your auto mid-GCD, you need to 3 tick it ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If you use your auto bind to recast your auto, you can alter what the auto will be when you cast it ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You can click to recast your auto mid-GCD ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If you click to recast your auto, your next ability must be at least 1 tick after otherwise you will override it ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- if you click to recast your auto ideally you do it mid-GCD so that you do not waste ticks ⬥ Thus, for Freedom we can do as follows: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Instead of the normal T0: Dual Wield Ability T3: Freedom + OH Auto Cast T4: 2H Auto cast T6: Ability ‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• We can instead do: T0: Dual Wield Ability T3: Freedom + OH Auto Cast T4: "Off" T6: 2H Auto + Ability Note: For both of these sample videos, Air Surge is the auto-casted spell and Fire Surge is the manually selected auto. I manually change the Defensive Auto to Fire Surge where possible for sake of demonstration ⬥ What are the differences between these two scenarios? ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The 2H Auto is cast and thus hits at different times ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• We can alter the 2H Auto in the second scenario, whereas in the first it will be whatever your autocasted spell is ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- We can alter the OH Auto in both scenarios by simply doing Other Auto → Freedom (e.g., → ) Note: This is how we can alter the Auto sent with Non-Damaging Abilities normally as well, though you can still alter it if you "off" for it and 3 tick it afterwards like the 2H Auto with Freedom . Common Applications of Defensive Autos ⬥ Applying Smoke Cloud with Sunshine ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Sunshine is a non-damaging ability, meaning an auto can be cast along with the following ability ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This benefit makes for a convenient time to apply Smoke Cloud, for example, at the start of the encounter: → ⬥ Magma Tempest (Targeted) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The targeted version of this ability can act as a non-damaging ability, meaning the following ability can be cast with a defensive auto ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- In order for it to act as such, it must be targeted onto the ground, not directly onto a target ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• For example, → on ground → ⬥ Avoiding weak abilities when staff camping ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• When camping staff, the lack of abilities at your disposal means it is possible you may have to fall back on weak basics such as Tuska's Wrath or Sacrifice ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Replace such abilities with Defensive + 2H Auto
docs.title: Defensive Autos

docs.text: This section will detail several switches that are useful for magic, and should be incorporated as comfortable and when relevant Juggling / ⬥ This is simply referring to making use of both dual wields and 2H, rather than camping one or the other ⬥ This is highly beneficial to do as it gives you access to both Greater Concentrated Blast and Sonic Wave ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This new filler ability aids in managing cooldowns and increasing overall damage output ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Moreover, it gives you all the benefits that camping either would provide to you ⬥ This is a good stepping stone for those that wish to move away from weapon camping but are either not willing or not confident enough to 4TAA Guthix Staff/Zamorak Staff / ⬥ This is a basic switch to incorporate into rotations, and is beneficial to do so where possible ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This is generally speaking bosses where you require the affinity debuff or if you have excess adrenaline to dump ⬥ When an Essence of Finality is acquired, / should generally be placed into it immediately ⬥ The main purpose of incorporating this switch is to make use of its special attack ⬥ There are a few considerations to list, and they are as follows: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It is beneficial to Ring of Vigour this special attack ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This brings the adrenaline cost from 25% to 22.5%. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If not using / , and you have Aftershock you will have to 0-tick your special attack in order to keep your Aftershock stacks ⬥ 0-ticking in this context refers to swapping from a weapon with Aftershock to Guthix Staff or Zamorak Staff , which does not have it, to a different weapon with Aftershock in the same tick ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Once again, this is never required if using / ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• 0-ticking works because the game only checks if Aftershock is equipped at the end of a tick ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Starting on Weapon A, to do this simply do: / → → Weapon B ⬥ If you 4TAA, you will generally wish to Auto into this special attack (as it is an Average Speed weapon, so think of it as a Staff Ability) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Thus, to 0-tick your spec starting on Weapon A you will have to: → / → equip Weapon B ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- If you do not wish to 0-tick your spec, then you do not need to do the weapon swap at the end on the same tick Planted Feet ⬥ This is a very strong switch that requires minimal effort to incorporate ⬥ This perk increases the duration of Sunshine at the cost of its Damage over Time (DoT) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It makes Sunshine's duration go from 52t/31.2s total (t0→51) to 64t/38.4s total (t0→t63) ⬥ Generally, always Sunshine with your Planted Feet switch ⬥ Common choices for a planted feet switch include a defender or an Enhanced Excalibur ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Placing it on a defender can potentially save an inventory space, as your shield is now also your planted feet switch ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Placing it on an Enhanced Excalibur also saves an inventory space wherever you would normally bring it ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Many bosses do not require a shield at all, in this case, Enhanced Excalibur potentially saves a space where a defender would not ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- It also means you can use the same switch for both Ranged and Magic ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- It is slightly more involved to use: requires clicking on ground so as not to be dragged into melee distance ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Planted feet can also be put on a cheap wand, though this is not generally recommended Flanking ⬥ This is a simple, yet strongly recommend switch to incorporate, especially for those doing group-based content ⬥ This turns Impact and Deep Impact into far stronger abilities at the cost of their stun which is largely irrelevant ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It increases Minimum of Impact by 8% per Flanking rank and its Max by 40% per Flanking rank ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It increases Minimum of Deep Impact by 6% per Flanking rank and its Max by 30% per Flanking rank ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Flanking Deep Impact is still not generally prioritized due to the availability of stronger thresholds Caroming ⬥ This is a more niche switch; however, in such cases it can be highly effective ⬥ This perk adds an additional target per rank to the Greater Chain and Chain abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• With Caroming 4 this means a total of 6 targets ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This is mostly beneficial to Greater Chain , as a combination of and strong abilities such as Igneous Omnipower can be massively effective at clearing mobs ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- The perk only needs to be equipped when casting Greater Chain , not when casting the follow-up ability ⬥ It is recommended to put this perk on either an off-hand switch, or a defender ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• A defender will produce lower damage on but can save an inventory space ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Consider combining and ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Lower damage on is generally not very detrimental, as the damage from the follow-up ability is what generates the largest portion of the resulting AoE damage ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Using an off-hand switch can be cheaper and higher damage on , however it will almost certainly cost an inventory space ⬥ A Caroming switch is recommended docs.text: What it is ⬥ 4-tick Auto Attack (4TAA), is an extension of weapon juggling wherein, as the name implies, you force an auto attack on the 4th tick after casting the ability before ⬥ As mentioned earlier, when you cast a damaging ability it will put your autos on cooldown ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• 4t cooldown after a fastest speed (wand) ability, 6t after an average speed (staff) ability ⬥ So to 4TAA, we make use of this fact, along with the fact that Magic can force an auto + ability on the same tick due to having access to spell (and thus auto) binds ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• We make use of this by delaying our next ability by a tick to force an auto and ability on the 4th tick How it Works ⬥ The general 4TAA structure without Greater Concentrated Blast will be like: 2H Auto + 2H/DW Ability → non-channelled DW Ability → (if DW Ability w/ Auto) Staff Swap → Repeat ⬥ The general 4TAA structure with gConc will be: Method A: 2H Auto + 2H/DW Ability → gConc → non-channelled DW Ability → (if DW Ability w/ Auto) Staff Swap → Repeat OR Method B: 2H Auto + gConc ‎ ‎→ DW Ability → non-channelled DW Ability → Staff Swap → Repeat ⬥ The difference between having and not having are as follows: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Instead of generally autoing every 2 abilities (7 ticks), it is every three abilities (10 ticks) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• In other words, ensure that you maximize casts by using it every 3rd ability ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Additionally, is always followed by a dual-wield ability, this is because swapping mainhands loses the crit buff ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• When you want to use Detonate or Asphyxiate (which ideally is 2-hit) it is the ability before ⬥ As you can see, when not using , the auto is forced every other ability. This is simply due to the fact that 2H autos have a 6t cooldown so you can only cast it after every other ability ⬥ Further, you can see the ability before it repeats (i.e., before you do your next auto + ability) has to be a non-channelled DW ability ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It must be a DW ability due to the 4t auto cooldown associated with it, allowing you to do a 2H auto 4t later ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It must be non-channelled because each hit of a channel resets your auto cooldown ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Thus it is generally ideal to always do an auto into your channelled ability, or at the very least do not do a channel before you intend to auto ⬥ Moreover, you can see that after an auto you can do either a 2H or DW ability, this is because it does not particularly matter assuming same perking and tiers ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• That being said, you must (outside of very niche cases without ) always ensure that when you do an auto into a channelled, that the channelled ability is done with DW (this is mostly important for Asphyxiate , as Concentrated Blast is already DW locked, and Smoke Tendrils is not relevant) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This is because of the fact that when the channelled hits it incurs your auto cd, it is going to incurs it based off the weapon you are wearing, thus if you staff , when your ends your auto is on a 6t cooldown again ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- The table below will showcase two different scenarios: 2H Asphyxiate: You MUST do: Auto + Asphyxiate → Ability → DW Ability → Auto + Ability DW Asphyxiate: You can do: Auto + Asphyxiate → DW Ability → Auto + Ability Note: this is not an issue if you do auto + ability → → non-channelled DW ability → repeat structure, given the fact you are already planning to auto 2 abilities after

docs.text: Video Guide by #Aiex https://youtu.be/HmZR1BBwsK0 Text Based Guide ⬥ The basic principles is you can do lossless spellcasting by hitting a spell from action bar (lossless meaning you don't lose ticks performing the action) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This lets you auto the same tick as you use an ability (input is auto → ability) ⬥ When you can autoattack is based on a delay depending on your weapon speed: = 4t and = 6t ⬥ ‎ ‎Your delay after an action is given by max(currentdelay, delay from action) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Implications from this are that if you do a wand ability you'll be able to autoattack 4 ticks after. If you do a staff ability, you will be able to autoattack 6 ticks after Step-By-Step 4TAA Walkthrough ⬥ Things you need: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Wand + Orb ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Staff ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Runes ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• An ability bar with the basic abilities: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Greater Concentrated Blast , Sonic Wave and a couple other basic abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Wrack ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Auto Attack (such as ) Note 1: is being used for practice solely due to its short cooldown, in actual PvM you should almost never be using this ability Note 2: is being used only for demonstration and cheap rune cost, replace as desired when PvMing ⬥ As touched on earlier, there are two fundamental patterns to 4TAA revolving around Greater Concentrated Blast ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Method A will be: 2H + DW/Staff ability → → DW ability → Repeat ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Method B will be: 2H + → DW/Staff ability → DW ability → Repeat Method A 1. Equip DW , acquire target, and Wrack 2. Equip Staff , wait 1 tick after GCD, then ( + ) in that order on the same tick 3. Equip DW , and Gconc 4. DW Wrack 5. Repeat from step 2 https://youtu.be/Ezn1gJpfRbs Method B 1. Equip DW , acquire a target, and Gconc 2. Cast a basic ability, for example, Dragon Breath (prefer DW to retain crit buff) 3. DW Wrack 4. Equip Staff , wait 1 tick after GCD, then ( + equip DW + ) in that order on the same tick 5. Repeat from step 2 https://youtu.be/NeWln6VcSSc 4TAA Additional Info ⬥ It can be helpful to practice on a combat dummy set to max hit mode, in order to more easily track whether or not you are properly executing 2H autos ⬥ Ensure that for necessary steps, all required actions are done within a single tick ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• For example, from method B, actions in the parentheses must be executed in one tick, in a specific order: DW ability + Equip staff → ( 2H + equip DW + ) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• To make this easier on yourself try keybinding your Wand/Orb/Auto in an easy to reach set of keybinds ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Some players prefer to click their auto attacks instead of keybind them, or in some cases even click their weapons. Such alternatives can be explored at the player's discretion ⬥ You will know you did not lose any ticks between auto and abilities if you do not see the auto firing animation, but the auto itself still fires

docs.text: While practising you may be unsure if you are messing up or not, so the following clips will showcase various scenarios: too fast, correctly, and too slow Note: the Auto damage in all the following clips is 2515 Too Fast This means you simply did not wait the additional tick required for the auto, and so casted your ability at GCD end instead of 1 tick after GCD end to get an Auto + Ability Correctly This means you did it correctly, this will demonstrate how it looks like in both Normals and Ancients Spellbooks ⬥ If you did not mess up on Normals, you will not get the Auto casting animation and you will see the auto still be fired out. ⬥ If you did not mess up on Ancients, you will not get the Auto casting animation. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• As you can also see, the Auto and Ability are cast as the GCD bar flashes Too Slow This means you were too late to cast your auto + ability, typically this results in a 5TAA (auto cast on tick 4, ability cast on tick 5), or worse (ability cast far later) More specifically, it means your ability will be delayed as your auto will automatically fire on the 4th tick either way, assuming you did not off

docs.text: Note: Many variations of FSOA rotations exist, and crit RNG is involved. This is simply a reference to start from An Overview of FSOA Usage ⬥ The Staff of Armadyl's immensely powerful special attack, Instability , consists of two components: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• An initial hit of 50%-200% ability damage ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Firing an auto-attack when a critical hit is landed ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- The auto casts the tick the hit lands ⬥ Auto-attacks released by can themselves crit. In such cases, auto-attacks will be fired recursively ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Recursively-fired auto-attacks will only occur if the critical hit lands on the primary target ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Crits on additional targets (such as from ) will not trigger the effect ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The damage of fired auto-attacks is determined by the equipped weapon when fired ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- For this reason, a 2H weapon should be preferred over dual-wields ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Fired auto-attacks will not interrupt channelled abilities; however, they will incur auto-attack cooldown ⬥ Due to Instability being focused around critical hits, it has excellent synergy with Tsunami for adrenaline generation from both abilities and subsequent auto-attacks ⬥ The special attack costs 50% adrenaline, lasts for 30 seconds, and has a cooldown of 60 seconds Key Considerations ⬥ An effective Staff of Armadyl rotation is made possible through landing critical hits with 2H equipped as often, and reliably as possible ⬥ As a result, Biting 4 , Erethdor's Grimoire , and a Reaver's Ring are essential ⬥ A Channeller's Ring is generally considered, at best, a marginal gain for Armadyl Battlestaff only. It is neither necessary, nor recommendable at its current price ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It does not affect the crit chance of autos produced by channelled abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Generally, it is considered very low priority ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Reaver's Ring is significantly better than Channeller's Ring if only one is camped ⬥ Generally, is the only dual-wield ability worth using under spec ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• As touched on above, care should be taken so as not to equip dual-wields after abilities such as , or channelled abilities, as this can result in MH autos being fired even if the abilities themselves were cast with 2H ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It is possible to → ability + equip in that order, same-tick, to receive the crit buff on the subsequent ability, and allow hit 3 of and the subsequent ability to fire 2H autos if they crit Basic Example Rotation ⬥ You can extend, modify, and improvise upon this rotation based on the particular situation and your crit RNG ⬥ Auto-cast is assumed to be Incite Fear until at least Tsunami ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Manual spellcasting is assumed to be enabled; therefore is simply used to 4TAA ⬥ Usage of the Igneous Kal-Mej and Conservation of Energy relic are assumed ⬥ Once is active, preferably use 2H for all abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Greater Concentrated Blast can be used to build adren mid-spec, keeping in mind the limitations specified above ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Smoke Tendrils will always crit each of its 4 hits ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This means it will fire at least 4 auto-attacks ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- It will also generate a large amount of guaranteed adrenaline under Tsunami → → → (optional strong basic, i.e. ) → → → ( if needed) → ( if needed) → → → → → Improvise Spell Swapping ⬥ Swapping auto-cast spells during an FSOA rotation can provide a host of benefits depending on the situation. Swapping will generally occur after necessary Incite Fear stacks are achieved for Tsunami ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Swapping to Blood Barrage , especially in AOE situations, can provide an immense amount of healing. As well, its fast hit timing can mean additional auto-attacks fitting within buffs from , , or itself ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Camping Incite Fear allows Frost Surge procs during , which have a chance to crit and subsequently fire auto-attacks ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Swapping to Exsanguinate allows for ability casts to build stacks that can benefit any usages of under ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- It may also grant more efficient access to after the spec has finished

docs.text: Dpm advice melee Introduction ⬥ In RuneScape PvM, the meta at the time of writing is about pushing out as much damage in as little time as possible. It is important to understand that good and efficient PvM, especially at the higher tiers, is about squeezing out as much damage as possible in between mechanics. This channel will go over general damage output lessons, ability prioritizations, crafting a rotation, a learning path, common mistakes, and tips and tricks. General Background Knowledge ⬥ For general PvM terminology, DPM tips, and revolution bars, see #dpm-advice-faq Ability Prioritizations & Building a Rotation Ability Prioritization ⬥ Generally speaking, high damaging abilities should be prioritized and used more often than low damaging abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• However, there's a catch. High damaging abilities often come with long cooldowns. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- If you use all of the high damaging abilities at once, you will be forced to wait for cooldowns before you may use them again – during which time you are forced to use low damage abilities. ⬥ To circumvent this, the trick is to use 'filler abilities'. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• For Melee these are just strong basics with short cooldowns, which will be used between your other high damaging but longer cooldowned abilities in order to pace your cooldowns. Note: You will have to use weak abilities like Fury as a filler ability should you be weapon camping ⬥ See this image for an idea of which abilities should be prioritized based on damage (in a vacuum): Note: You should not necessarily use abilities in the listed order due to aforementioned reasons. Building a Rotation ⬥ When building a rotation, ability prioritizations AND cooldowns should be on your mind. ⬥ You want to make sure to prioritize usage of Assault and Destroy / Cane / as these are your strongest thresholds, where ideally they are used your Berserk and generally the first couple thresholds you use. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Also, if cooldowns and adrenaline permit outside of they are of high priority too, such as using them in ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Outside of , especially the Masterwork Spear of Annilihation you would want to prioritize bleed thresholds such as Slaughter too. ⬥ Blood Tendrils has 45s cd so you can only use it once per zerk cycle (i.e., per 1 minute cycle) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This means you have a great deal of flexibility with when you use it so should balance it around maximising other thresholds ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This is not to say that you should ignore Blood Tendril usage, it is just to say you have greater flexibility of when to slot it into your rotation ⬥ There are certain thresholds that your focus should be cooldown management ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• These include Slaughter, Assault, and sometimes Cane/Destroy ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- These are your strongest thresholds, but also have the tightest cooldowns in terms of maximizing usage/minute ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• In contrast, there are abilities that would not define your ability rotation as strictly such as Cleave, which is what is considered filler in between these ⬥ Filler abilities such as Cleave and Decimate should be used in-between other high damage but longer cooldowned ability such as Sever , Dismember , and flank Backhand ⬥ Any basic ability with equal-or-lower damage than 2-hit Fury / Greater Fury / would be considered a weak ability (Barge , Smash , Havoc , Slice , and Punish ). ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Generally speaking, these should be avoided. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- There are cases and conditions where is on average better than what are referred to as 188 abilities ( / / ), this will be discussed later. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If you are DW or 2H camping you will likely have to regularly weave in (2-hit) / more often as your weakest ability. ⬥ If you are 2H or DW camping, you will be limited to only one strong filler ability (Cleave or Decimate , respectively). Thus, try to utilize Cleave or Decimate as often as possible in your rotation. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• / becomes another one of your filler abilities, albeit it is weaker than what is typically a melee filler ability ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- A basic pattern of (2-hit) / → Ability → Ability → Repeat is recommended for camping rotations. ⬥ For weapon juggling, you will have access to both Cleave and Decimate as your filler abilities. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This lets you have more breathing room in what rotations and fillers you create. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• While there is no singular rotation that is best here, a general pattern of Cleave → Decimate → Ability → Ability → Repeat will work. Weapon Camping Assuming you camp dual-wield, then it largely does not matter - though you should ideally pick up a MH Non-Mace due to higher auto damage, which you will make use of as you Berserk assuming you are not going to use Greater Barge . Weapon Juggling When it comes to juggling (i.e., making use of both 2H and dual-wield weaponry), the choice is a bit more important: ⬥ You want a MH Mace , due to its fastest weapon speed: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This allows you to 5-tick Auto Attack (5TAA) if need be. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This also means you can 4-tick Auto Attack (4TAA) debuff spells such as Smoke Cloud too. ⬥ You also want an OH non-Mace , due to its fast weapon speed: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This results in your offhand auto damage in being a bit higher, which only sees use when you Freedom . Other Considerations There are cases where you may want to choose a mainhand based on being able to exploit weaknesses (e.g., Drygore Rapier for the Rex Matriarch Rathis), but these are more niche, the above is more general. 5TAA Note: Any time a speed is before an auto/ability (e.g., "Average Ability") this simply refers to the weapon speed used to cast it What It is ⬥ This is pretty similar to 4TAA, but for Melee, in that you are essentially delaying your next ability to get an auto in; however, a key difference is that Melee does not have an auto bind, and so must wait an additonal tick before casting their ability ⬥ So, instead of doing: T0: Fastest non-channeled Ability T4: Auto + Ability ⬥ You do T0: Fastest non-channeled Ability T4: Auto auto-casts T5: Ability ⬥ Video Demonstration (Courtesy of #NamoV): ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Abilities used in clip: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- → (wait 4t) auto fires → (wait 1t) ⬥ The reason for this is because Autos normally are executed after abilities in a tick, so using an ability on the same tick it is casted will override it as it incurs the auto cooldown, hence the need to delay the ability an additional tick to get the auto in 5TAA with revolution ⬥ With Revolution active, after casting a fastest non-channeled ability, you will have to use Cease (or off by other means) before Revolution triggers your next ability. Then, click on your target 4t after your initial ability casted, which is 1t after the GCD ends (i.e., when your ability bar flashes), to force an auto attack. Follow it up with your next ability 1t after the auto. ⬥ Video Demonstration: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Abilities used in clip: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- + → (wait 4t) click on target → (wait 1t) When It is Used ⬥ 5TAA is primarily done to align ticks, this is most notably seen in Berserk rotations that use one 7t channel (e.g., 4-hit Destroy ) without the ability to use a 5t channel (e.g., 3-hit Greater Flurry ) to align ticks, as can be seen below: T0: Zerk T3: Ability T6: Ability T9: 7t channeled Ability T16: Ability T19: Ability T22: Fastest non-channeled Ability T26: Auto auto-casts T27: Ability T30: Ability T33: Ability + Zerk ends ⬥ ‎ ‎As you can see in the above table, by using a 5TAA it was possible to get an ability on the last tick of , this then allows any ability to hit outside of and thus get both and Berserker Aura damage modifiers Note: You can read more on this interaction in #mechanics ⬥ It is important to note that the ability before must be a fastest non-channeled ability or your auto will be on cooldown ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Further the ability before that cannot be a slower-than-fastest channeled ability otherwise your auto would still be on cooldown ⬥ Video Demonstration of Berserk with 5TAA to align ticks: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Abilities used in clip: + → → → → → (4-hit) → → → (fastest) → (5taa) ⬥ Video Demonstration of Berserk without 5TAA to align ticks: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Abilities used in clip: + → → → → → (4-hit) → → → (fastest) → → Difference in the Above Clips As seen, they both follow the same ability order, except the first has an auto, and the other has a non-boosted Decimate after Quake ⬥ In the clip where 5TAA is used, does more damage (8451 vs 7644) ⬥ This is because by making using of 5TAA it was possible to realign the Zerk rotation to get an ability on the last tick of to get the Ultimate and Aura buff ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Doing a 7t (4.2s) channel will require you to do this to realign to last tick of ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- An alternate way to realign is to use a 5t (3.0s) channel ⬥ The after the was used to display how you cannot fit another ability by skipping the auto anyway, so to make full use of ticks you want to 5TAA ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The benefits of this is gone in more in depth in this video by #Aiex: https://youtu.be/AzswBOuBnUQ Applying Smoke Cloud How to Apply It There are two ways to go about applying Smoke Cloud with Melee: ⬥ Using Freedom ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Replacing the offhand auto for Smoke Cloud by doing → ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- It is worth noting this requires an offhand autocast spell like Polypore Strike to be set beforehand, as well as an offhand Magic weapon being equipped ⬥ 4-ticking it ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Similar to doing 5TAA, except you will do + Ability on the 4th tick, instead of doing an ability on the 5th tick ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- 4th/5th tick are in relation to the ability before it being on tick 0 ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This costs an additional tick compared to using . So, if done in Berserk , it is important to be wary of the following to ensure you realign back to final tick of : ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- If a 7t channel is done in then you will have to do another 7t channel, or somehow drop a tick somewhere (e.g., 1t earlier before a fight starts) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- If a 7t channel is not done then you will have to 5TAA or do a 5t channel Issues with Melee Using Smoke Cloud While it is still worth applying, Melee struggles the most with applying the spell due to having a shorter ultimate than the other styles, as well as the fact that with Greater Barge you cannot just use Smoke Cloud as you start the fight, it would have to be casted mid-Zerk after your Barge. docs.text: ⬥ In RuneScape PvM, the meta at the time of writing is about pushing out as much damage in as little time as possible. It is important to understand that good and efficient PvM, especially at the higher tiers, is about squeezing out as much damage as possible in between mechanics. This channel will go over general damage output lessons, ability prioritizations, crafting a rotation, a learning path, common mistakes, and tips and tricks.

docs.text: Ability Prioritization ⬥ Generally speaking, high damaging abilities should be prioritized and used more often than low damaging abilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• However, there's a catch. High damaging abilities often come with long cooldowns. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- If you use all of the high damaging abilities at once, you will be forced to wait for cooldowns before you may use them again – during which time you are forced to use low damage abilities. ⬥ To circumvent this, the trick is to use 'filler abilities'. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• For Melee these are just strong basics with short cooldowns, which will be used between your other high damaging but longer cooldowned abilities in order to pace your cooldowns. Note: You will have to use weak abilities like Fury as a filler ability should you be weapon camping ⬥ See this image for an idea of which abilities should be prioritized based on damage (in a vacuum): Note: You should not necessarily use abilities in the listed order due to aforementioned reasons. Building a Rotation ⬥ When building a rotation, ability prioritizations AND cooldowns should be on your mind. ⬥ You want to make sure to prioritize usage of Assault and Destroy / Cane / as these are your strongest thresholds, where ideally they are used your Berserk and generally the first couple thresholds you use. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Also, if cooldowns and adrenaline permit outside of they are of high priority too, such as using them in ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Outside of , especially the Masterwork Spear of Annilihation you would want to prioritize bleed thresholds such as Slaughter too. ⬥ Blood Tendrils has 45s cd so you can only use it once per zerk cycle (i.e., per 1 minute cycle) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This means you have a great deal of flexibility with when you use it so should balance it around maximising other thresholds ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This is not to say that you should ignore Blood Tendril usage, it is just to say you have greater flexibility of when to slot it into your rotation ⬥ There are certain thresholds that your focus should be cooldown management ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• These include Slaughter, Assault, and sometimes Cane/Destroy ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- These are your strongest thresholds, but also have the tightest cooldowns in terms of maximizing usage/minute ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• In contrast, there are abilities that would not define your ability rotation as strictly such as Cleave, which is what is considered filler in between these ⬥ Filler abilities such as Cleave and Decimate should be used in-between other high damage but longer cooldowned ability such as Sever , Dismember , and flank Backhand ⬥ Any basic ability with equal-or-lower damage than 2-hit Fury / Greater Fury / would be considered a weak ability (Barge , Smash , Havoc , Slice , and Punish ). ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Generally speaking, these should be avoided. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- There are cases and conditions where is on average better than what are referred to as 188 abilities ( / / ), this will be discussed later. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If you are DW or 2H camping you will likely have to regularly weave in (2-hit) / more often as your weakest ability. ⬥ If you are 2H or DW camping, you will be limited to only one strong filler ability (Cleave or Decimate , respectively). Thus, try to utilize Cleave or Decimate as often as possible in your rotation. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• / becomes another one of your filler abilities, albeit it is weaker than what is typically a melee filler ability ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- A basic pattern of (2-hit) / → Ability → Ability → Repeat is recommended for camping rotations. ⬥ For weapon juggling, you will have access to both Cleave and Decimate as your filler abilities. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This lets you have more breathing room in what rotations and fillers you create. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• While there is no singular rotation that is best here, a general pattern of Cleave → Decimate → Ability → Ability → Repeat will work.

docs.text: Desired Channel Lengths ⬥ In almost all scenarios, you will cancel Fury on its 2nd hit, this is as your Global Cooldown ends (3t/1.8s) ⬥ Typically you will cancel your Assault and Destroy on the 4th hit (7t/4.2s) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• To cancel on 3rd hit you would cancel on t5 (3s) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• To cancel on 2nd hit you would cancel on t3 (1.8s) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- The above cancel timings are the same for Flurry , Greater Flurry , and Frenzy 2H vs Dual Wield Assault ⬥ Assault hit splats will land at different times depending on whether it is cast with 2h or DW. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The timing to cancel it remains unchanged. Assuming a T0 Assault cast, it hits on ticks: 2 4 6 8 for 2H 3 5 7 9 for DW When to Cancel Greater Flurry Unlike other Melee channels, sees regular use of both 2-hit and 3-hit versions of itself, as well as some cases for 4-hitting it, this section will give a general idea of when each is used: ⬥ 2-hit ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• No Relentless Limitless Berserks ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- E.g.: Bled → (2-hit) → Basic → ⬥ 3-hit ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• General Apot Berserks (where only 1 7t channel is used) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This is done to realign ticks so you can get an ability on the last tick of ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Relentless Limitless Berserks ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- E.g.: Bled → (3-hit) → , where the proc is on or ⬥ 4-hit ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• When Berserk cooldown is important ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If your Berserk will not end so the tick offset is not an issue ⬥ For more information on cancelling, refer to #Evil Lucario's Video on cancelling https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=unCtj7IosVA Note: The Buff Bar timers are outdated in this video, for up-to-date timers check: https://youtu.be/y33z3WLM7H8

docs.text: This section is meant to list the benefits of camping one over the other though it is strongly recommended to just juggle, as it gives access to all the following benefits, and more. 2H Benefits ⬥ Better AoE capabilities ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This due to access to Cleave , Hurricane , and Quake Dual Wield Camp Benefits ⬥ Easier swapping ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You can swap to Shield or Flanks more easily, as you do not need to do an additional mainhand swap Note: The reason why offhand swaps are used can be read by doing !ohswitches in #bot-commands
docs.title: Dual Wield vs 2H Camp

docs.text: This section will detail several switches that are useful for magic, and should be incorporated as comfortable and when relevant. Juggling / ⬥ This is simply referring to either adding a Dual Wield swap or 2H swap depending on if you currently 2H camp or Dual Wield Camp. ⬥ This is highly beneficial to do as it gives you access to Decimate or Cleave respectively. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Thus, it gives you a new filler ability to make use of and so you can manage cooldowns more effectively and also increase your average damage overall. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Moreover, it gives you all the benefits that 2H camping and Dual Wield camping alone provides. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Furthermore, you are now able to get lossless 2H autos with non-damaging abilities (i.e., defensive autos) such as and Flanking ⬥ This is a simple, yet strongly recommend switch to incorporate, especially for those doing group-based content. ⬥ This turns Backhand and Forceful Backhand into far stronger abilities at the cost of their stun which is largely irrelevant ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It increases Minimum of by 8% per Flanking rank and its Max by 40% per Flanking rank ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It increases Minimum of by 6% per Flanking rank and its Max by 30% per Flanking rank ⬥ It is recommended to put this perk on an off-hand switch ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Reduces the damage and accuracy loss of using a lower tier weapon for switch (Khopesh MH + Drygore OH > Drygore MH + Khopesh OH ) Masterwork Spear of Annilihation ⬥ Its effect is that it adds two additional hits to the following abilities: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Dismember (bringing it to 7 from 5 hits, and up to 10 with the Strength Cape effect) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Slaughter (bringing it to 7 from 5 hits) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Blood Tendrils (bringing it to 7 from 5 hits) ⬥ While this weapon could used as your primary t92 2H weapon, it is better to use it as a switch for the above 3 abilities as you can perk it to have to boost damage and getting full benefit of normal DPS perks on your remaining abilities.

docs.text: Note: While this section is colloquialy referred to as "Defensive Autos", it is more technical to say they are non-damaging abilities, and so includes things like Berserk and the Zaros Godsword spec . Why Defensive Autos Exist ⬥ Typically, when you cast an auto or ability it put your Auto on cooldown based on the weapon speed of the weapon it was cast with ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Cooldowns for various weapon speeds are as follows: Speed (cooldown in ticks/seconds) Slowest (12t/7.2s) Average (6t/3.6s) Fast (5t/3.0s) Fastest (4t/2.4s) Note: Any time a speed is before an auto/ability (e.g., "Average Ability") this simply refers to the weapon speed used to cast it ⬥ Non-damaging abilities are the exception to this rule, so if you cast one it will not put your auto on cooldown What This Means ⬥ If you cast a fast/fastest ability into a defensive ability, your auto will happen mid Global Cooldown (GCD) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• For Melee this will just be your default auto, though you can alter it to a debuff spell like still by doing → Defensive ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The following table will break down the ticks of this: T0: Fast/Fastest Ability T3: Defensive T4/5: Auto is cast T6: Ability ⬥ Video Demonstration (Courtesy of #NamoV): ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Abilities used in clip: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- → → ‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Further, you can exploit this to make it a 2H auto, as the cooldown for any auto ends on t4 ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- So, you would simply swap to a 2H weapon between the Fast/Fastest Ability cast to before the Auto would be cast Freedom It is important to note that Freedom works a little differently, in that you will get both an off-hand and a main-hand/2H auto ⬥ You will always get the off-hand auto, and what is cast as an off-hand auto can be changed by doing auto → on the same tick. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• To do this with Melee you will need an off-hand magic weapon on (e.g., Ancient Lantern ), and to have an offhand autocast spell set (Polypore Strike recommended) ⬥ An example of getting both offhand and 2H auto can be seen in this clip by #Wh: https://youtu.be/YydKrY05Kc8 ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It is important to stress that you should not swap to 2H too early, otherwise you will lose the offhand auto. You should swap 1t after you cast

docs.text: The Basics Greater Barge can be unlocked by consuming a Greater Barge Ability Codex. Greater Barge works as follows: ⬥ It will break you free of binds, and where applicable bind a target for 11 ticks (6.6sec) ⬥ By default has a damage range of 25%-125% ⬥ For each tick (0.6sec) since the player stopped attacking their target, Greater Barge gains +10% to its max damage range, and +2% to its min ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This caps at 10 tick (6s) for +100% and +20%, for a final range of 45%-225% ⬥ If it has been atleast 8 ticks (4.8sec) since you stopped attacking it gains another effect, indicated by the Greater Barge icon appearing on your Buff Bar, then it gains an additional effect: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Any melee channeled ability used within 10 ticks (6sec) of casting Greater Barge, indicated by the a Provoke-like icon appearing on your Buff Bar, will be turned into a damage-over-time (DoT) instead ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- For the sake of simplicity converting a channeled ability into a DoT is referred to as "bleeding" it, or having "bled" it, or you are going to "bleed" that threshold; however, these should not be confused with normal bleeds (e.g. ), as they are different. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Further, this is the actual reason Greater Barge is so strong When It Is Used Greater Barge is commonly used as follows, in the following cases: ⬥ First is simply at the start of a fight, as you should not have attacked anything long enough and thus can freely Greater Barge and then convert a channeled ability into a DoT ⬥ Secondly is after any mechanic that forces you to off, such as Vorago's Reflect mechanic, as you again should not have attacked anything long enough allowing you to then Greater Barge freely ⬥ The third case is stalling your rotation mid-combat before you to get the effect within it, which is done as follows: Exploring How to Execute the Third Case Properly ⬥ Damaging Ability (e.g. ) → click off atleast 1 tick (0.6sec) before your Defensive → Defensive (e.g. ) → Berserk → Greater Barge ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• It is important to click off atleast 1 tick prior otherwise you will not get the effect ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This is thought to be because the game thinks you have tried to cast an auto as a result of the Defensive, and so resets the Greater Barge effect timer ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Also, as seen here, there are 9 ticks (5.4sec) between the the Damaging Ability and Greater Barge, which is 1 more tick (0.6sec) than required ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- So, if said Ability gets you the adrenaline to Berserk , then it is a tick (0.6s) more efficient to do as follows: ⬥ Damaging Ability (e.g. ) → wait 2 ticks (1.2sec) → Berserk → Greater Barge ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• As seen here, there are now 8 ticks (4.8sec) between the Damaging Ability and Greater Barge ⬥ Here is a demonstration: https://youtu.be/GPPMjY2wrjw The Cost of Using Greater Barge In general the cost of utilizing Greater Barge is an Auto in say your Berserk , but in the third case the cost is a Damaging Ability (e.g. ) + your Auto. Though the benefit is an extra 4 ticks in say your Berserk which is large enough to be worth said cost. Notes on Greater Barge Note: bullets marked with ★ are likely bugs, or at the very least unintended ⬥ Unlike normal non-damaging abilities, while ZGS spec will not incur the auto cooldown, it will still try to drag you in to auto ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Therefore, if you want to → mid combat, you need to click off again as you to not auto and lose the buff ⬥ Multiple people can stack their Greater Barge bled abilities, unlike what would be possible with normal bleed abilities ⬥ If you bleed Greater Flurry all the hits will reduce your Berserk cooldown, as you allow its full duration to channel now ⬥ ★ If you using queuing, if you have no target, ensure to not queue your Greater Barge before TCing and using it, otherwise you will not get the buff to bleed a channeled ability ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Similar issues occur when clicking over TCing, though likely not a bug, but important to be aware of nonetheless ⬥ ★ Greater Barge also does not give adrenaline if you still have a target that is dead ⬥ ★ If for whatever reason you were to bleed Frenzy , it only does 180% hits ⬥ Equipping a different tier of weapon after bleeding will change the damage of the weapon according to the latter weapon tier ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This occurs as it is still attempting to cast each hit separately, like a normal channel ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This also means each hit has its own chance to hit ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• For example, of you bleed with a t90 weapon equipped, then switch to t92 the damage will be calculated as t92 damage for any remaining hits ⬥ Vorago will not clear these DoTs on reflect ⬥ The hit timings of Greater Barge bleeds follow a fixed pattern: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The first hit's hit timing corresponds with the time it would normally hit as a channeled ability ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- For example, 2H Assault hit 1 would be 2t (1.2sec) delayed, whereas DW Assault hit 1 would be 3t (1.8sec) delayed ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Hits 2-4 will always hit 5t, 7t, and 9t (3sec, 4.2sec, 5.4sec) delayed respectively ⬥ ★ Further if you stall a barge bleed the following will occur: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Hits 2-4 will hit as normal on the target you casted the ability on to stall ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Hit 1 will be the only hit that gets stalled, and when released will hit the same time as it would normally hit if it were the first hit of its channeled ability ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Furthermore, what this means is you can far-cast your barge bleed on a target to make hits 2-4 hit it from a large distance technically Greater Fury Greater Fury can be unlocked through consuming a Greater Fury Ability Codex. This does a few things things: ⬥ Firstly, Fury is no longer a 3-hit channeled ability and instead only hits once dealing 157% ability damage (the same as the first two hits of the channeled version) ⬥ Secondly, the passive 5% critical hit chance increase per channelled hit changes to a single 10% critical hit chance increase on the next hit ⬥ Thirdly, it gains an extra effect where getting a critical hit on Greater Fury gives you a buff which guarantees the first hit of your next ability will crit ⬥ The main benefit to this upgrade is transforming this ability from a 3-hit (5t/3.0s) channeled ability to a 1-hit non-channeled ability, and so it only requires a GCD to fully use. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This allows Greater Fury to be used in Revolution++ and Revolution setups without needing to manually cancel the channel after 2 hits. ⬥ Due to the guaranteed crit effect, it is possible for to be stronger (on average) than a 188% ability ( / / ) ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This is only possible when the crit chance of and the ability damage of the following ability are sufficiently high. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Currently, the only cases where these requirements are met are when you are under the effects of an active Grimoire (and have Biting perk ), and the ability following is either a flanked ability or a charged Greater Barge . ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Another niche consideration is when under the effects of Berserk (and ), there is almost no damage difference between → and 188% → . ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Without the active effects of , is basically always weaker than a 188% ability. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- Despite this, if you are put into a position where you have no 188% abilities available and need to use , you should consider following it up with a >188% ability to still maximise your damage. *Note: A sheet comparing to / / before various abilities can be found here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1beHYkyPKV-tj8eHlbRDQTRX9GkdFBKhBr89B8fKyuXI/edit#gid=1063393167 *

docs.text: Note: 99% of the time it will be MH Mace, OH Non-Mace , this section just goes in more depth of varying scenarios Disclaimer It is important to initially make clear that all Drygore weaponry does the same ability damage, and the differences in choices occur due to other properties they have, such as side-effects due to their weapon speeds. Weapon Camping Assuming you camp dual-wield, then it largely does not matter - though you should ideally pick up a MH Non-Mace due to higher auto damage, which you will make use of as you Berserk assuming you are not going to use Greater Barge . Weapon Juggling When it comes to juggling (i.e., making use of both 2H and dual-wield weaponry), the choice is a bit more important: ⬥ You want a MH Mace , due to its fastest weapon speed: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This allows you to 5-tick Auto Attack (5TAA) if need be. ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- This also means you can 4-tick Auto Attack (4TAA) debuff spells such as Smoke Cloud too. ⬥ You also want an OH non-Mace , due to its fast weapon speed: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This results in your offhand auto damage in being a bit higher, which only sees use when you Freedom . Other Considerations There are cases where you may want to choose a mainhand based on being able to exploit weaknesses (e.g., Drygore Rapier for the Rex Matriarch Rathis), but these are more niche, the above is more general.

docs.text: Note: Any time a speed is before an auto/ability (e.g., "Average Ability") this simply refers to the weapon speed used to cast it What It is ⬥ This is pretty similar to 4TAA, but for Melee, in that you are essentially delaying your next ability to get an auto in; however, a key difference is that Melee does not have an auto bind, and so must wait an additonal tick before casting their ability ⬥ So, instead of doing: T0: Fastest non-channeled Ability T4: Auto + Ability ⬥ You do T0: Fastest non-channeled Ability T4: Auto auto-casts T5: Ability ⬥ Video Demonstration (Courtesy of #NamoV): ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Abilities used in clip: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- → (wait 4t) auto fires → (wait 1t) ⬥ The reason for this is because Autos normally are executed after abilities in a tick, so using an ability on the same tick it is casted will override it as it incurs the auto cooldown, hence the need to delay the ability an additional tick to get the auto in 5TAA with revolution ⬥ With Revolution active, after casting a fastest non-channeled ability, you will have to use Cease (or off by other means) before Revolution triggers your next ability. Then, click on your target 4t after your initial ability casted, which is 1t after the GCD ends (i.e., when your ability bar flashes), to force an auto attack. Follow it up with your next ability 1t after the auto. ⬥ Video Demonstration: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Abilities used in clip: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- + → (wait 4t) click on target → (wait 1t) When It is Used ⬥ 5TAA is primarily done to align ticks, this is most notably seen in Berserk rotations that use one 7t channel (e.g., 4-hit Destroy ) without the ability to use a 5t channel (e.g., 3-hit Greater Flurry ) to align ticks, as can be seen below: T0: Zerk T3: Ability T6: Ability T9: 7t channeled Ability T16: Ability T19: Ability T22: Fastest non-channeled Ability T26: Auto auto-casts T27: Ability T30: Ability T33: Ability + Zerk ends ⬥ ‎ ‎As you can see in the above table, by using a 5TAA it was possible to get an ability on the last tick of , this then allows any ability to hit outside of and thus get both and Berserker Aura damage modifiers Note: You can read more on this interaction in #mechanics ⬥ It is important to note that the ability before must be a fastest non-channeled ability or your auto will be on cooldown ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Further the ability before that cannot be a slower-than-fastest channeled ability otherwise your auto would still be on cooldown ⬥ Video Demonstration of Berserk with 5TAA to align ticks: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Abilities used in clip: + → → → → → (4-hit) → → → (fastest) → (5taa) ⬥ Video Demonstration of Berserk without 5TAA to align ticks: ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Abilities used in clip: + → → → → → (4-hit) → → → (fastest) → → Difference in the Above Clips As seen, they both follow the same ability order, except the first has an auto, and the other has a non-boosted Decimate after Quake ⬥ In the clip where 5TAA is used, does more damage (8451 vs 7644) ⬥ This is because by making using of 5TAA it was possible to realign the Zerk rotation to get an ability on the last tick of to get the Ultimate and Aura buff ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Doing a 7t (4.2s) channel will require you to do this to realign to last tick of ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎- An alternate way to realign is to use a 5t (3.0s) channel ⬥ The after the was used to display how you cannot fit another ability by skipping the auto anyway, so to make full use of ticks you want to 5TAA ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The benefits of this is gone in more in depth in this video by #Aiex: https://youtu.be/AzswBOuBnUQ
